titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to John H. Tait, January 27, 191[4]
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Year not inscribed but is attributed to 1914 by letter events. John H. Tait was with the 1st U.S. Volunteer Cavalry (Roosevelt Rough Riders) during the Spanish American War, May 1-September 30, 1898. Tait is listed as a Roosevelt Rough Rider in the 1899 and 1902 BBWW route books but does not appear in the 1900 route book. Lewis H. Baker, a/k/a Johnny Baker (1869-1931), was Cody's foster son and a sharpshooter in BBWW.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to John H. Tait

msIdentifier.repository: McCracken Research Library, John H. Tait Collection

div1.p: Your letter came Johnny got in with some great dope yesterday is being gotten ready to go to Washington along with the Indian picturerspictures.2 Johnny may go in to old Mexico with a movie outfit.3 DontDon't suppose you want any of that. Eh?
IllI'll be back from Washington in a week.

back.note: Note 1: Although Cody did not include the year when dating this letter, the context indicates that it was written in 1914. Cody went to Washington, D.C. in February 1914 to show his film The Indian Wars to audiences that included senior officials in the Interior and War Departments.

Note 3: A letter from Cody to Tait, dated simply "Jan. 22" but believed to be written in 1914, apparently refers to Baker sending images of "the Mexican Army & Refugees" to Cody who describes Baker's material as "great stuff."
